com.telek.telekmath.advanced.statistics.inferential

Class ConfidenceIntervals

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.telek.telekmath.advanced.statistics.inferential.ConfidenceIntervals

  • public class ConfidenceIntervals
extends java.lang.Object
    A class that calculates mean, proportion and variance confidence intervals for one or two populations.
    All these methods calculate an estimated interval for the population's mean/proportion/variance.
    For more information please look here

    • Method Detail

      • getIntervalForMean

        public static TRange getIntervalForMean(DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                        double populationStddev,
                                        double alpha)
        Returns the confidence interval (CI) for the population's mean when the population's standard deviation is known.
        If the population is normally distributed, this method will return exact results. And if not, then it will return approximate results.
        Parameters:
        sampleDesc - the sample's DataDescription object
        populationStddev - the population's known standard deviation
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the population mean

      • getIntervalForMean

        public static TRange getIntervalForMean(DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                        boolean isNormallyDist,
                                        double alpha)
        Returns the confidence interval (CI) for the population's mean when the population's standard deviation is unknown.
        You will need to specify the distribution type with the `isNormallyDist` parameter.
        If you don't know the distribution type then just enter false.
        If the population is normally distributed, this method will return exact results. And if not, it will return approximate results.
        Parameters:
        sampleDesc - the sample's DataDescription object
        isNormallyDist - a boolean value specifying the distribution type, you need to enter true if this sample is normally distributed, if you don't know what type of distribution this data has then just enter false
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the population mean

      • getIntervalForProportion

        public static TRange getIntervalForProportion(DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                              int successes,
                                              double alpha)
        Returns the confidence interval (CI) for the population's proportion according to the successes parameter.
        There are many methods to calculate the CI for population's proportion such as Jeffreys, Agresti-Coull, Wilson, Clopper-Pearson exact and Normal approximation.
        This method uses Normal approximation to calculate the CI, meaning that it uses ZDist to determine it's initial interval before calculating the error.
        Also if the population is normally distributed, this method will return exact results. And if not, then it will return approximate results.
        To check if your samples are approximately normally distributed or not, you can use the isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed(DataDescription, double) method.
        Parameters:
        sampleDesc - the sample's DataDescription object
        successes - specifies how many successes are in this sample, the definition of a "success" may change
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the population proportion

      • getIntervalForProportion

        public static TRange getIntervalForProportion(DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                              double pHat,
                                              double alpha)
        Returns the confidence interval (CI) for the population's proportion.
        Parameters:
        pHat - rate of successes in this sample (definition of success may change)
        sampleDesc - the sample's DataDescription object
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the population proportion
        See Also:
        getIntervalForProportion(DataDescription, int, double)

      • getIntervalForDiffOfMeansKnown

        public static TRange getIntervalForDiffOfMeansKnown(DataDescription desc1,
                                                    DataDescription desc2,
                                                    double populationStddev1,
                                                    double populationStddev2,
                                                    double alpha)
        This method calculates the confidence interval for the difference of population means by using ZDist class when the standard deviations of these populations are known.
        To be honest us knowing these populations' standard deviations are somewhat an unrealistic assumption but sometimes this assumption is met and we can use this method to calculate confidence intervals.
        In statistics, in order to calculate this interval we make the assumption that both of these populations are normally distributed. If they're not we won't get an exacty answer.
        But even if they're not normally distributed (or we just don't know what type of distributions they have) we can still use this method to do an approximation by passing our samples' standard deviations as our populations' standard deviation values.
        Parameters:
        desc1 - first sample's description
        desc2 - second sample's description
        populationStddev1 - first population's (known) standard deviation
        populationStddev2 - second population's (known) standard deviation
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the difference of population means

      • getIntervalForDiffOfMeansKnown

        public static TRange getIntervalForDiffOfMeansKnown(double sampleCount1,
                                                    double sampleCount2,
                                                    double sampleMean1,
                                                    double sampleMean2,
                                                    double populationStddev1,
                                                    double populationStddev2,
                                                    double alpha)
        See Also:
        getIntervalForDiffOfMeansKnown(DataDescription, DataDescription, double, double, double)

      • getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny

        public static TRange getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny(DataDescription desc1,
                                                         DataDescription desc2,
                                                         double alpha)
        This method calculates the confidence interval for the difference of population means by using ZDist class when the distribution types and standard deviations of these populations are unknown.
        This method gives approximate results using getIntervalForDiffOfMeansKnown(DataDescription, DataDescription, double, double, double) method. For more information look at that method's javadocs.
        Parameters:
        desc1 - first sample's description
        desc2 - second sample's description
        sampleStddev1 - first sample's standard deviation
        sampleStddev2 - second sample's" standard deviation
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the difference of population means

      • getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny

        public static TRange getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny(double sampleCount1,
                                                         double sampleCount2,
                                                         double sampleMean1,
                                                         double sampleMean2,
                                                         double sampleStddev1,
                                                         double sampleStddev2,
                                                         double alpha)
        See Also:
        getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny(DataDescription, DataDescription, double)

      • getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownNormal

        public static TRange getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownNormal(DataDescription desc1,
                                                            DataDescription desc2,
                                                            boolean assumeEqualStddevs,
                                                            double alpha)
        This method calculates the confidence interval for the difference of population means when the standard deviations of these populations are unknown and the populations are normally distributed.
        In statistics, in order to get exact results even when the populations' stddev values are unknown we need the populations to be normally distributed. That's why this method assumes that both populations are normally distributed. If your populations are not normally distributed (or if you simply don't know what type of distribution they have you can always use getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny(DataDescription, DataDescription, double) method to get approximate resulsts. For more information look at that method's javadocs.
        Most of the times in real life statistics when you calculate degrees of freedom as a non-integer value you round it to get better and approximate results. This method does not do approximations for degrees of freedom and uses real valued degrees of freedoms. For example if degrees of freedom is calculated as 10.751 you would round this to 11 but this method does not do this and takes it as 10.751.
        Parameters:
        desc1 - first sample's description
        desc2 - second sample's description
        assumeEqualStddevs - a boolean specifying if these two populations have the same variances or not, if you have no idea about this equality just enter false
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the difference of population means

      • getIntervalForDiffOfMeansUnknownNormal

      • getIntervalForDifferenceOfProportions

        public static TRange getIntervalForDifferenceOfProportions(DataDescription desc1,
                                                           DataDescription desc2,

                                                           int successes2,
                                                           double alpha)
        See Also:

      • getIntervalForDifferenceOfProportions

        public static TRange getIntervalForDifferenceOfProportions(double sampleCount1,
                                                           double sampleCount2,
                                                           double pHat1,
                                                           double pHat2,
                                                           double alpha)
        Returns the confidence interval (CI) for the difference of population proportions.
        If the population is normally distributed, this method will return exact results. And if not, then it will return approximate results.
        To check if your samples are approximately normally distributed or not, you can use the isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed(DataDescription, double) method.
        Parameters:
        sampleCount1 - first sample's count
        sampleCount2 - second sample's count
        pHat1 - rate of successes in the first sample (definition of success may change)
        pHat2 - rate of successes in the first sample (definition of success may change)
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        The confidence interval (CI) for the difference of population proportions

      • isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed

        public static boolean isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed(DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                                         double pHat)
        Returns true if this sample is approximately normally distributed.
        You can use this method to check if your sample fits a confidence interval for proportions calculation or not.
        Parameters:
        sampleDesc - sample's description
        pHat - rate of successes as a double value (successes / count)
        Returns:
        true if this sample is approximately normally distributed

      • isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed

        public static boolean isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed(double sampleCount,
                                                         double pHat)
        See Also:
        isApproximatelyNormallyDistributed(DataDescription, double)
